section.title: Ethical Issues and Scientific Integrity
section.content: Ethical Issues and Scientific Integrity Ethical issues can arise at this point. We’ll consider two such issues: Fraud, and Plagiarism. Ethical Issues and Scientific Integrity Ethical issues can arise at this point. We’ll consider two such issues: Fraud, and Plagiarism.

section.title: Ethical Issues and Scientific Integrity
section.content: Ethical Issues and Scientific Integrity APA has ethical standards that relate to fraud and plagiarism. Specifically, section 6.21 states: “Psychologists do not fabricate data or falsify results in their publications” and “If psychologists discover significant errors in their published data, they take reasonable steps to correct such errors in a correction, retractions, erratum, or other appropriate publication means.” Ethical Issues and Scientific Integrity APA has ethical standards that relate to fraud and plagiarism. Specifically, section 6.21 states: “Psychologists do not fabricate data or falsify results in their publications” and “If psychologists discover significant errors in their published data, they take reasonable steps to correct such errors in a correction, retractions, erratum, or other appropriate publication means.”

section.title: Ethical Issues and Scientific Integrity
section.content: Ethical Issues and Scientific Integrity In section 6.22, the APA specifies: “Psychologists do not present substantial portions or elements of another’s work or data as their own, even if the other work is cited occasionally.” Ethical Issues and Scientific Integrity In section 6.22, the APA specifies: “Psychologists do not present substantial portions or elements of another’s work or data as their own, even if the other work is cited occasionally.”

section.title: Fraud in Science
section.content: Fraud in Science Important to distinguish between error and fraud. An error is an honest mistake that occurs in the research process. Many opportunities for errors in research: In collecting data, In scoring measures, In entering data into a computer, In publication typesetting. Fraud in Science Important to distinguish between error and fraud. An error is an honest mistake that occurs in the research process. section.title: Fraud in Science
section.content: Fraud in Science Fraud is an explicit effort to deceive and misrepresent data. If a researcher makes up or changes data to support a hypothesis, this is fraud. The essential goal of science is to discover knowledge and reveal truth. Fraud the ultimate enemy of the scientific process. section.title: The (Sad) Case of Diederik Stapel
section.content: The (Sad) Case of Diederik Stapel Stapel was a prominent Dutch social psychologist. Research misconduct committed by Stapel was vast. involves manipulation of data and complete fabrication of entire experiments. The fraudulent data used in at least 58 published, peer-reviewed papers. A number of dissertations are thought to be based on fabricated data. Colleagues of In June 2013 Stapel agreed, in a settlement, to perform 120 hours of community service and to lose benefits associated with his former job equivalent to a year and a half's worth of salary. section.title: Why Is Fraud in Science Committed?
section.content: Why Is Fraud in Science Committed? The primary cause of fraud is the competitive nature of an academic career. There is strong pressure on researchers to have their research published. Why Is Fraud in Science Committed? The primary cause of fraud is the competitive nature of an academic career. There is strong pressure on researchers to have their research published.

section.title: Safeguards Against Fraud
section.content: Safeguards Against Fraud Fortunately, several safeguards help keep fraud in check. Science is public. Other researchers read reports and conduct further studies, including replications. This is the primary means of revealing error and uncovering fraud in research. section.title: Plagiarism
section.content: Plagiarism To present someone else’s ideas or words as your own. Plagiarism, like fraud, is a serious breach of ethics. Plagiarism To present someone else’s ideas or words as your own. Plagiarism, like fraud, is a serious breach of ethics.

section.title: Plagiarism
section.content: Plagiarism Reference citations must be included in your paper. Done: Whenever someone else’s ideas or work has influenced your thinking and writing, Whenever you use direct quotations, Whenever you paraphrase someone else’s work. section.title: Plagiarism
section.content: Plagiarism If an idea or information you include in a paper is not originally yours, you must cite it. For students, the penalties for plagiarism may include: A failing grade on the paper or the course, and Expulsion from the institution. For faculty, the penalties for plagiarism are much the same as those for fraud. Plagiarism If an idea or information you include in a paper is not originally yours, you must cite it. section.title: Plagiarism
section.content: Plagiarism Plagiarism can occur on a variety of different levels. At one extreme, you can literally copy an entire paper word for word and present it as your own work. In this case, the plagiarism is clearly a deliberate act committed with complete awareness. Plagiarism Plagiarism can occur on a variety of different levels. At one extreme, you can literally copy an entire paper word for word and present it as your own work. In this case, the plagiarism is clearly a deliberate act committed with complete awareness.

section.title: Plagiarism
section.content: Plagiarism Plagiarism can be much more subtle occurring without your direct knowledge or intent. After working on a project for an extended amount of time, it can be difficult to separate your own words and ideas from those that come to you from outside sources. section.title: Plagiarism
section.content: Plagiarism Guidelines developed by Myers and Hansen (1997) can help prevent you from plagiarizing: Take complete notes, including: Author’s name, Year of publication, Title of the article, Journal name, Volume number, and Page numbers. For books, include the publisher’s name and city. section.title: Plagiarism
section.content: Plagiarism Within your paper, identify the source of any ideas, words, or information that are not your own. Identify any direct quotes by quotation marks at the beginning and end of the quotes, and indicate where you got the quotes. section.title: Plagiarism
section.content: Plagiarism Be careful about paraphrasing (restating someone else’s words). It is tempting to lift whole phrases or catchy words from another source. Use you own words instead, or use quotes. Be sure to give credit to your source. Plagiarism Be careful about paraphrasing (restating someone else’s words). It is tempting to lift whole phrases or catchy words from another source. Use you own words instead, or use quotes. Be sure to give credit to your source.

section.title: Plagiarism
section.content: Plagiarism Include a complete list of references at the end of the paper. References should include all the information listed in item 1 of this list (e.g., author’s name, journal name, etc.) If in doubt about whether a citation is necessary, cite the source anyway. section.title: APA Style: Journal Articles, One Author
section.content: APA Style: Journal Articles, One Author Mellers, B. A. (2000). Choice and the relative pleasure of consequences. Psychological Bulletin, 126(6), 910-924. https://doi.org/10.1037/0033-2909.126.6.910 Notice the font – Times New Roman (or Courier) is used Font size is 12-point. You may now use Calibri 11-pt., Ariel 11-pt., Lucida 10-pt., Sans Unicode 10-pt, Georgia 11-pt., The entry is double spaced. A hanging indent is used. The author’s last name is written followed by first initial and middle initial. Next comes the year the article was published. The title of the article is next. Only the first word in the title is capitalized. Next, the journal name is presented. All words in the journal name are capitalized and it is italicized. Next the volume number is presented. It is italicized. Then comes the issue number. Finally, the page numbers are presented. If the work has a doi, present it even if you read the printed (vs. online) version. section.title: Issue Numbers
section.content: Issue Numbers If an article has an issue number, present it after the volume number. Do not italicize. Klimonski, R., & Palmer, S. (1993). section.title: Books
